problems.question: You see a cell under the microscope. It is striated (striped), contains many nuclei in one cell, and is attached to bone. What type of cell is this?
options: Skeletal muscle
Cardiac muscle
Smooth muscle
Tendon
problems.hint: Striations and multinucleation attached to bone indicate skeletal muscle.
problems.detailed: Skeletal muscle fibers are long, cylindrical, striated, multinucleated, and attach to bones to produce voluntary movement. Correct answer: A.
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda

problems.question: Which choice correctly contrasts cardiac muscle with smooth muscle?
options: Cardiac: involuntary, striated, has intercalated discs; Smooth: involuntary, non-striated, found in the GI tract
Cardiac: voluntary, non-striated; Smooth: voluntary, striated
Cardiac: mononucleated and voluntary; Smooth: multinucleated and involuntary
Cardiac: found in the GI tract; Smooth: makes up the heart wall
problems.hint: Both are involuntary, but cardiac is striated with discs; smooth is non-striated.
problems.detailed: Cardiac muscle is involuntary, striated, and has intercalated discs; smooth muscle is involuntary, non-striated, and found in organs like the GI tract. Correct answer: A.
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda

problems.question: A weightlifter increases training intensity and, over months, their muscles become larger. What is this change called and which is a direct cause mentioned in the theory text?
options: Hypertrophy — muscle fibres grow larger due to increased physical strain
Atrophy — muscle fibres contract in length so they grow in size from exercise
Hypertrophy — muscles get more nuclei because of starvation causing them to grow
Atrophy — muscles swell from increased activity
problems.hint: Muscles grow larger in response to exercise, not smaller.
problems.detailed: Hypertrophy is the increase in muscle fiber size due to consistent physical strain or resistance training. Correct answer: A.
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda

problems.question: A motor neuron stops working for one muscle. Where does a healthy motor neuron normally meet the muscle fiber, and which neurotransmitter does it release there?
options: Neuromuscular junction; acetylcholine
Synaptic cleft on bone; dopamine
Intercalated disc; norepinephrine
Tendon junction; serotonin
problems.hint: Think of the special synapse between nerve and muscle.
problems.detailed: A motor neuron releases acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction to trigger muscle contraction. Correct answer: A.
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda

problems.question: Why is ATP required both for muscle contraction and for muscle relaxation?
options: ATP powers myosin movement for contraction and also lets myosin detach and helps pump calcium back for relaxation
ATP is only used for contraction; relaxation is passive and needs no ATP
ATP creates actin; without ATP there is no actin to contract
ATP cools the muscle during exercise so it can relax
problems.hint: ATP is needed both to move myosin and to detach it.
problems.detailed: ATP hydrolysis powers myosin head movement for contraction and allows detachment during relaxation. It also powers calcium pumps in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Correct answer: A.
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda

problems.question: In a sarcomere diagram the labels mean: A = region containing only thin (actin) filaments; B = region that contains thick (myosin) filaments; C = structure that anchors thin filaments and marks the sarcomere boundary. Which label is the I band, A band, and Z disc respectively?
options: I band = A, A band = B, Z disc = C
I band = B, A band = C, Z disc = A
I band = A, A band = B, Z disc = C
I band = C, A band = A, Z disc = B
problems.hint: I band = thin only, A band = thick, Z disc = boundary.
problems.detailed: I band consists of actin only (A), A band contains thick myosin filaments (B), and Z disc anchors actin and marks sarcomere boundaries (C). Correct answer: C.
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda

problems.question: A child bends their elbow to throw a ball (bringing the hand closer to the shoulder). Is that motion a flexion or an extension, and which muscle primarily produces it?
options: Flexion — biceps brachii
Extension — triceps brachii
Flexion — triceps brachii
Extension — biceps brachii
problems.hint: Bending the arm = flexion; front of upper arm muscle?
problems.detailed: Flexion at the elbow is produced by the biceps brachii. Correct answer: A.
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda

problems.question: Why are intercalated discs important in cardiac muscle?
options: They contain gap junctions that allow rapid electrical conduction so cells beat together
They store calcium for long contractions
They prevent blood from entering the muscle fibers
They make cardiac muscle voluntary
problems.hint: They allow cardiac cells to contract as a unit.
problems.detailed: Intercalated discs contain gap junctions for rapid electrical conduction, coordinating heart contractions. Correct answer: A.
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda

problems.question: Put these steps of voluntary muscle activation in the correct order: 1 = Acetylcholine binds receptors on the muscle fiber; 2 = Motor neuron fires an impulse; 3 = Myosin heads bind actin and perform a power stroke; 4 = Calcium is released inside the muscle fiber and moves troponin/tropomyosin
problems.hint: Impulse fires first, neurotransmitter binds, calcium released, then contraction.
problems.detailed: Motor neuron fires (2), acetylcholine binds (1), calcium released and moves troponin/tropomyosin (4), myosin binds actin and performs power stroke (3). Correct answer: A.
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda
